snippet: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Friday's selection includes a blogger's tale of buying the e-mails of a million Facebook users, and Facebook's response; and a look at Apple...
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Friday's selection includes a blogger's tale of buying the e-mails of a million Facebook users, and Facebook's response; and a look at Apple and political donations.

headline.main: Today's Scuttlebot: Facebook E-Mail Sales and Twitter in Politics

snippet: China’s cooling economy is squeezing American exporters, Apple introduced the iPad Mini, and Microsoft unveiled Windows 8 as well as its new tablet, the Surface.

headline.main: Pictures From the Week in Business

snippet: His mother never made it to the cow-flecked hills, majestic cliffs, friendly pubs and potato-rich meals of her Irish roots. But, finally, he did.

headline.main: To Ireland, a Son’s Journey Home

snippet: From basketball courts to Fox News, by way of a walrus’s snout.
Wall Street struggled as investors reacted without enthusiasm to a series of weak earnings reports and the news of only tepid economic growth.
abstract: Stocks finish flat, recovering from moderate declines as investors react without enthusiasm to a series of weak earnings reports and news of tepid economic growth.

headline.main: Weak Earnings Hold the Markets Back
headline.print_headline: Weak Earnings Hold the Markets Back

snippet: The Chinese government blocks access to The New York Times Web site after it published an article on the family fortune of China's prime minister, Apple's quarterly results shows its might, and the estate of William Faulkner sues over a quote in a...
abstract: The Chinese government blocks access to The New York Times Web site after it published an article on the family fortune of China's prime minister, Apple's quarterly results shows its might, and the estate of William Faulkner sues over a quote in a Woody Allen movie.

headline.main: The Breakfast Meeting: China Blocks Times's Sites, and Faulkner v. Allen

snippet: Apple and Amazon both reported quarterly earnings on Thursday. For Apple, it was a story of increasing profits. But Amazon reported its first quarterly loss in four years.
abstract: Apple and Amazon both reported quarterly earnings on Thursday. For Apple, it was a story of increasing profits. But Amazon reported its first quarterly loss in four years.

headline.main: Daily Report: Apple Has Higher Profit, While Amazon Has a Loss

snippet: The family of China's prime minister has had remarkable business success in the years since he came to power. | The coup at Citigroup that toppled Vikram S. Pandit was meticulously planned over the last several months. | Xstrata has set up "a diab...
abstract: The family of China's prime minister has had remarkable business success in the years since he came to power. | The coup at Citigroup that toppled Vikram S. Pandit was meticulously planned over the last several months. | Xstrata has set up "a diabolical game of the prisoner's dilemma," the Deal Professor writes. | With the presidential election around the corner, business leaders are engaging in some political activism.

headline.main: Wealth and Politics Converge in China

snippet: British activists are calling for action to stem tax avoidance by big multinational corporations. But their calls for boycotts are presenting consumers with some tough ethical choices.
abstract: British activists are calling for action to stem tax avoidance by big multinational corporations. But their calls for boycotts are presenting consumers with some tough ethical choices.

headline.main: Storm in a Coffee Cup Over Corporate Tax Loopholes

snippet: The Treasury Department said Thursday that a communications firm with close ties to President Obama talked to the administration about allowing tax breaks for its corporate clients on more than $1 trillion in offshore revenues.
abstract: Treasury Dept says that SKDKnickerbocker, communications firm with close ties to Pres Obama, talked to administration about allowing tax breaks for its corporate clients on more than $1 trillion in offshore revenues; firm has insisted that it never lobbied senior Treasury officials.

headline.main: Treasury Says Firm Discussed Tax Break
headline.print_headline: Treasury Says Firm Discussed Tax Break

byline.original: By ERIC LICHTBLAU and ERIC LIPTON
